intro: Acacia cyclosperma, commonly known as the whistling thorn, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa. It is characterized by its long, thorned stems and compound leaves that are adapted to reduce water loss. The plant produces yellow flowers that are clustered in cylindrical spikes, attracting pollinators such as bees and birds. Its seeds are enclosed in pod-like fruits that split open when mature, dispersing the seeds by wind. Acacia cyclosperma plays a vital role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various desert animals.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia cyclosperma is primarily native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, including countries such as Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and South Africa. It is commonly found in savannas, woodlands, and along riverbanks where it thrives in well-drained soils. This plant is also present in parts of the Arabian Peninsula and the Indian subcontinent. It plays an important ecological role by providing food and shelter for various wildlife species. Due to its adaptability, it can also be found in disturbed areas and degraded landscapes.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia cyclosperma was mainly introduced to South Africa, where it has become naturalized in various regions. It is commonly found in coastal areas, sandy soils, and along roadsides. The plant is known for its ability to thrive in harsh environmental conditions, making it a successful invader in new habitats. Its rapid growth and prolific seed production contribute to its spread and ecological impact. However, it is also valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a source of fodder for livestock.
